<@U2WAP0R6J> if your target network is set up from fabric master, you should use new code in fabric-sdk-node to run against it. hfc installed from npm would be for v0.6 and won’t work with v1.0-level network.

if you want to test the v1.0-level network, you can get a feel of how things are supposed to work by running the tests: test/unit/end-2-end.js, how to set up the network so you can run the tests in your native host is described in the README: <https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-sdk-node>
Is HFC 0.5.3 the right/compatible version to use with the Bluemix Beta right now?

<@U2WAP0R6J> also, the v1.0 level code both on the network side (repo “fabric”) and client side (repo “fabric-sdk-node”) have not been updated to support TCerts yet, so chaincodes that need TCerts like the asset_management*.go won’t work just yet
<@U2RCN8W95> yes that’s still the case for a few more days
bluemix is being updated to the latest fabric version (v0.6)
believe it’s going out soon
Where is the best place to learn of when that refresh takes place?
<@U0PB67X4K> <@U0YR44350> would know the exact timing

<@U2WAP0R6J> from the error it seems the “vendor” folder is missing, when deploying using the node.js SDK, you need to make sure that the manual preparation was done, namely, you need to create a “vendor” folder next to the .go code for your chaincode, and populate that with the fabric source tree
as described here: <http://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/nodeSDK/node-sdk-indepth/#chaincode-deployment>

text: <@U0KQ9QKH6> that’s indication that your local keyvaluestore (saving enrollment certs) and the member service are out of sync.
you can clean this up by 1) re-init member service (if using docker-compose, add “—force-recreate” to the end after “up”) 2) delete local keyvaluestore (usually set to /tmp/keyValueStore)
actually I am running with --force-recreate
ah 2) helped
new error though:

ALL ( <@U0Z81GL6S> <@U1KFBBWG1> <@U1L2C9F3R> <@U1C3LNJ58> <@U1AJV5S2G> <@U2Q0HP4HY> <@U0KQ9QKH6>  ), note that the peer code in fabric master has been upgraded to the latest protobuf design, so the fabric-sdk-node APIs no longer work. if you want to test the current fabric-sdk-node code, you need to reset your fabric code to this commit level: 597c9441d501325f64b941517571e6650fd2c147

text: I think it's due to a missing env var that would specify the address (and port?) of the orderer service.  My digging around in the peer golang codebase suggested that the line from fabric/core/committer/noopssinglechain/committer.go  ```orderer := viper.GetString("peer.committer.ledger.orderer")``` is what determines the orderer's address, and as I gather, the string is transformed into CORE_PEER_COMMITTER_LEDGER_ORDERER.
Adding the line ```    - CORE_PEER_COMMITTER_LEDGER_ORDERER=orderer:5005``` seemed to fix this problem.
<@U2X9KDDL7> the direction is correct...

I would suggest creating a docker-compose.yml file in the test/unit subdir which would run those services and in another service, run the tests.  I've written such a docker-compose.yml file and am testing it now.
sounds good
<@U2X9KDDL7> thanks for catching that, I’ve added it to the README and updated <http://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/2161> (for FAB-927)
<@U0KQ9QKH6> this will fix the error you saw that prevented transactions from being committed to the ledger (thus not causing events to fire)
<@U13TWBRBL> Thanks!
